verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses and Aaron in the land of Egypt:
verses.comment: This introduces a new section with direct speech from God.

verses.text: "This month will be for you the beginning of months; it will be the first month of the year for you.
verses.comment: The Hebrew calendar is set around God's deliverance.

verses.text: Speak to all the congregation of Israel, saying, 'On the tenth day of this month each man must take a lamb for himself, according to their fathers’ households, one lamb for each household.
verses.comment: Fathers’ households is a literal rendering of 'house of their fathers.'

verses.text: But if the household is too small for a whole lamb, then he and his neighbor next to his house must take one according to the number of people; you must take into account how much each person will eat.
verses.comment: Maintains the wording about household size and eating.

verses.text: Your lamb must be without blemish, a male a year old; you may take it from the sheep or from the goats.
verses.comment: ‘Without blemish’ is a key phrase for ritual purity.

verses.text: You must keep it until the fourteenth day of this month, then all the congregation of Israel will kill it at twilight.
verses.comment: Twilight is literally ‘between the evenings’ in Hebrew.

verses.text: They must take some of the blood and put it on the two doorposts and on the lintel of the houses where they eat it.
verses.comment: ‘Lintel’ is the upper part of the doorframe.

verses.text: They must eat the meat that night, roasted in fire; with unleavened bread and bitter herbs they must eat it.
verses.comment: Literal order: roasted, unleavened bread, bitter herbs.

verses.text: Do not eat any of it raw or boiled in water, but roasted in fire, with its head, its legs, and its inner parts.
verses.comment: Hebrew: 'head, legs, and entrails.'

verses.text: You must not leave any of it until the morning; whatever remains until the morning you must burn with fire.
verses.comment: Direct command about remaining meat (full consumption).

verses.text: This is how you must eat it: with your belt fastened, your sandals on your feet, and your staff in your hand. You must eat it in haste. It is the LORD’s Passover.
verses.comment: ‘Belt fastened’ is a literal translation for readiness.

verses.text: For I will pass through the land of Egypt that night, and I will strike all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both man and beast; and I will execute judgment against all the gods of Egypt. I am the LORD.
verses.comment: Reference to judgments on Egyptian gods.

verses.text: The blood will be a sign for you on the houses where you are. When I see the blood, I will pass over you, and no plague will be among you to destroy you when I strike the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: ‘Pass over’ is where Passover receives its name.

verses.text: This day will be a memorial for you, and you must keep it as a feast to the LORD; throughout your generations, as a statute forever, you must keep it as a feast.
verses.comment: ‘Statute forever‘ is a literal rendering.

verses.text: For seven days you must eat unleavened bread. On the first day, you must remove leaven out of your houses, because anyone who eats anything leavened from the first day until the seventh day, that person must be cut off from Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Cut off’ means to be excommunicated from the community.

verses.text: On the first day there will be a holy assembly, and on the seventh day a holy assembly. No work must be done on those days, except what everyone must eat; only that is permitted for you.
verses.comment: Holy assembly (Heb: miqra qodesh) means a sacred gathering.

verses.text: You must observe the Feast of Unleavened Bread, for on this very day I brought your armies out of the land of Egypt. You must observe this day throughout your generations, as a statute forever.
verses.comment: ‘Armies’ (Hebrew: hosts) refers to the people of Israel.

verses.text: In the first month, from the fourteenth day of the month at evening, you must eat unleavened bread, until the twenty-first day of the month at evening.
verses.comment: Specific timing given in Hebrew: 'in the evening.'

verses.text: For seven days no leaven is to be found in your houses. If anyone eats what is leavened, that person will be cut off from the congregation of Israel, whether he is a sojourner or a native of the land.
verses.comment: Sojourner means foreigner residing among them.

verses.text: You must eat nothing leavened; in all your dwellings you must eat unleavened bread."
verses.comment: Command for all living spaces, not just households.

verses.text: Then Moses called all the elders of Israel and said to them, "Go and select lambs for yourselves according to your families, and kill the Passover lamb.
verses.comment: Follows closely the Hebrew command structure.

verses.text: Take a bunch of hyssop, dip it in the blood that is in the basin, and apply some of the blood that is in the basin to the lintel and the two doorposts. None of you may go out of the door of his house until morning.
verses.comment: Hyssop is a ceremonial plant used for sprinkling.

verses.text: For the LORD will pass through to strike the Egyptians, and when he sees the blood on the lintel and on the two doorposts, the LORD will pass over the door and will not allow the destroyer to enter your houses to strike you.
verses.comment: ‘The destroyer’ refers to the angel of death or judgment.

verses.text: You must observe this as a statute for you and for your sons forever.
verses.comment: Transmission of instructions to descendants is emphasized.

verses.text: When you enter the land that the LORD will give you, as he has promised, you must observe this service.
verses.comment: Reference to fulfillment of God’s promise.

verses.text: And when your children say to you, 'What do you mean by this service?'
verses.comment: ‘What do you mean’—literal Hebrew: 'What is this service to you?'

verses.text: You must say, 'It is the sacrifice of the LORD's Passover, for he passed over the houses of the people of Israel in Egypt, when he struck the Egyptians but spared our houses.'" And the people bowed down and worshiped.
verses.comment: Worship is a direct translation of the Hebrew ‘prostrated.’

verses.text: Then the people of Israel went and did this; as the LORD had commanded Moses and Aaron, so they did.
verses.comment: Repetition for emphasis as in the Hebrew text.

verses.text: At midnight the LORD struck down all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of Pharaoh who sat on his throne, to the firstborn of the captive who was in the dungeon, and all the firstborn of the cattle.
verses.comment: All social classes and even captives are included.

verses.text: Pharaoh rose up in the night, he and all his servants and all the Egyptians, and there was a loud cry in Egypt, because there was not a house where someone was not dead.
verses.comment: ‘Loud cry’ is literal Hebrew (unique and great wailing).

verses.text: Then he called Moses and Aaron by night and said, "Rise, go out from among my people, both you and the people of Israel; go, serve the LORD, as you have said.
verses.comment: Pharaoh concedes fully to Moses' request.

verses.text: Take your flocks and your herds, as you have said, and be gone, and bless me also!"
verses.comment: Pharaoh asks for a blessing from Moses’ God.

verses.text: The Egyptians urged the people to hurry and leave the land, for they said, "We will all be dead!"
verses.comment: Egyptians feared further destruction.

verses.text: So the people took their dough before it was leavened, with their kneading bowls bound up in their clothes on their shoulders.
verses.comment: Literal detail preserved from Hebrew.

verses.text: The people of Israel had also done as Moses told them, for they had asked the Egyptians for silver and gold jewelry, and for clothing.
verses.comment: ‘Asked’ (or ‘demanded’) is literal in Hebrew.

verses.text: The LORD gave the people favor in the sight of the Egyptians, so they gave them what they asked. So they plundered the Egyptians.
verses.comment: ‘Plundered’ is a military term for taking spoils.

verses.text: The people of Israel journeyed from Rameses to Succoth, about six hundred thousand men on foot, besides children.
verses.comment: ‘Men on foot’ excludes women and children, as in Hebrew.

verses.text: A mixed multitude also went up with them, and flocks and herds, a very large number of livestock.
verses.comment: ‘Mixed multitude’ refers to non-Israelite peoples with them.

verses.text: They baked unleavened cakes of the dough that they had brought out of Egypt, because it was not leavened, for they were driven out of Egypt and could not wait, nor had they prepared any provisions for themselves.
verses.comment: ‘Otherwise leavened’ is omitted, literal is ‘it was not leavened.’

verses.text: Now the time that the people of Israel lived in Egypt was four hundred and thirty years.
verses.comment: 430 years is literal from MT and LXX.

verses.text: At the end of four hundred and thirty years, on that very day, all the armies of the LORD went out from the land of Egypt.
verses.comment: ‘Armies’ (hosts) refers to divisions or families.

verses.text: It was a night of watching for the LORD, to bring them out of the land of Egypt; so this night remains a night of watching for the LORD by all the people of Israel throughout their generations.
verses.comment: ‘Watching’ means ‘watchful vigil’—key ritual element.

verses.text: The LORD said to Moses and Aaron, "This is the statute of the Passover: no foreigner may eat of it;
verses.comment: ‘Foreigner’ (Hebrew: ben-nekar) means a non-Israelite.

verses.text: but every servant who is bought for money may eat of it after you have circumcised him.
verses.comment: Circumcision as entry to covenant is emphasized.

verses.text: A temporary resident and a hired worker may not eat of it.
verses.comment: ‘Temporary resident’ is a literal translation of Hebrew ‘toshav.’

verses.text: It must be eaten in one house; you must not take any of the meat outside the house, and you must not break any of its bones.
verses.comment: Links to Messianic prophecy in the New Testament.

verses.text: All the congregation of Israel must keep it.
verses.comment: Applies corporately to all Israel.

verses.text: If a stranger sojourns with you and wants to keep the Passover to the LORD, every male in his household must be circumcised. Then he may come near and keep it; he must be as a native of the land. But no uncircumcised person may eat of it.
verses.comment: ‘Stranger sojourning’ includes foreigners living long-term.

verses.text: There must be one law for the native and for the stranger who sojourns among you."
verses.comment: Unity of Torah (law) for Israel and sojourners is emphasized.

verses.text: All the people of Israel did just as the LORD commanded Moses and Aaron.
verses.comment: Phrase emphasizes obedience, as in the Hebrew repetition.

verses.text: On that very day the LORD brought the people of Israel out of the land of Egypt by their armies.
verses.comment: ‘By their armies’ (or hosts) means as organized groups.
